instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
Struggling with this board that was very clean.
The S5 rails are jumping up and down from 50% to 100%.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 13v steady
Charger 20v 0.01A
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> jumping 2.5v-5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping 1.5v-3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.4v

<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> pulsing 0 - 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> diode mode around 18K.
<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL> pulsing
<CHIP>U7650</CHIP> replaced - still pulsing
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> replaced - still pulsing

It doesn't appear to charge the battery either, but the cell voltage was really low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
Looks like a problem in a secondary power supply.
First of all, try to start in SMC bypass, to discard a SMC sensor issue.
Next, check if any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse at least.
Check for short on all big coils.
Any pulse at L7670?
What about <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message: Does CPU VCore pulse as well?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
Thanks for the response guys.
Tried SMC bypass, no difference.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> shows 20mv every now and then, but otherwise 0v.
Nothing on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 0v.

It doesn't get anywhere through the power up sequence, so there's no Vcore.

There's no pulses on L7670 as there's no <SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> signal.

<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> right? I'm not getting this cos its dependent on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> via <CHIP>U8205</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
"Tried SMC reset, no difference."
[I] I said SMC BYPASS; many times explained on the forum...[/I]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
Sorry, typo. It was a bypass, not a reset.

The battery should still charge even without S5 state shouldn't it?

Also, just discovered <SIGNAL>PP1V_S5</SIGNAL> has a short. It's 1R. That's gotta be too low surely?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message: If VCore doesn't pulse check all rails for shorts seems you may have found one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
I've injected voltage into the <SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> rail but couldn't find anything getting remotely hot. It took 1v at 1a.
I've also noticed <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> is also low resistance. I hope this doesn't mean the CPU is blown.
I removed FET <TRANSISTOR>Q8060</TRANSISTOR> but the short is still there on the <SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> rail 

[I]Can anyone else provide readings for these rails on a good board please?[/I]

Other observations are:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> jumping 2.5v - 5v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> steady 3.4v

Diode mode tests:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 0.439v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> 0.40v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 0.40v

I'm trying to figure out if it's a short or a signal problem.
Any advice greatly appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
"It took 1v at 1a"
That means 1W only.
Probably nor even FLIR cam will detect something; but could be an option to try.
You can also inject until 1.3V without risk.

Lift pin1/L8060 ans see where the short remains.
If on pin2, then is probably bad CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
I've temporarily removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8060</TRANSISTOR> which is just before L8060 and the short was still there.

I'm going to check the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> circuit to see if there's an issue on this rail as the other side <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, appears OK even though the voltage is briefly there.

However, I thought the board would stick in S5 state if it couldn't get into S4 and wouldn't reboot as this board seems to be doing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
"I've temporarily removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8060</TRANSISTOR>"
<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is still connected there.
That's the reason I told you to lift L8060.

If S5 voltages pulse, board could try to move into S4, or something connected to S5 rails is bad.
Did you try the board alone, without anything connected?
Only charger, eventually USB mouse.

Remove <RESISTOR>R7661</RESISTOR>/62 and see if get steady voltage at L7670/90.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> S5 rails not steady
threads.message:
OK, with L8060 removed, 43K on pin1, 1R on pin2. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> still jumping.

I just have the board on the bench, nothing else connected.

<RESISTOR>R7662</RESISTOR> removed, no 3v3 S5.
<RESISTOR>R7661</RESISTOR> removed, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> still jumping up to 5v (?!)

I'm going to try injecting in to each S5 rail to make sure they're OK.
